The raw numbers of the foreign: born population in the United States have increased over the years and reached a peak of about 40 million in 2012, which is the highest it has been since the Census started tracking it.
However: when considering the percentage of foreign-born residents in relation to the total population, the current foreign-born population of 12.9% is not the highest it has ever been. It was higher from 1860 through the 1920s.
The trend of increasing numbers of forei: born residents has been observed since 1970, with the percentage reaching almost 13% in 2010, which is close to the all-time high in the 1890s.
Experts suggest that measuring the forei: born population as a percentage of the total population is a more useful approach to determine the country's ability to accommodate immigrants.
